title: How to stay healthy on a plane
text:
A colleague had been on a plane - and he felt a cold coming on. With watery eyes and a red nose, he asked, "Have you written about how to stay healthy on flights?"

Getting sick after a flight is a common complaint for a few reasons. Flyers are squeezed together. Planes are filled with germ-ridden surfaces and the circulating air at 30,000 feet (9100m) has low humidity. Also, jet lag can mess with a person's immune system.

A comfortable and thus happier traveller spends more money, research found Shutterstock

How to fight those forces?

"Handwashing is the single most important infection control measure," according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Wash with soap and water for at least 20 seconds - and touch nothing in the lavatory afterwards without the shield of a paper towel. Hand rubs with at least 60 per cent alcohol will do the trick if soap and water are unavailable. Avoid touching your nose, mouth and eyes with unwashed hands.
description: Getting sick after a flight is a common complaint for a few reasons. Here's how to fight it.
